metadata.title: A brief network analysis of Artificial Intelligence publication

sections.text: In this paper, we present an illustration of the history of Artificial Intelligence (AI) with a statistical analysis of publications since 1940. We have collected and evaluated the IEEE data to analyze the geological and chronological variance of research activity in the field of Artificial Intelligence. The result shows that the leading community of AI research is mainly located in the United States, China, Europe and Japan. Key institutes, authors and research priorities are revealed. It is also shown that research institutes are very active in the fields of data mining, computer vision, Pattern Recognition and some other areas of machine learning, implying strong interaction between individual areas. It is also shown that research in the field of electrical engineering and industrial or commercial applications is very active in California. Japan also publishes a lot of essays in robotics. Due to the limitation of the data source, the result could be overly influenced by the number of published articles that best benefit from the application of the "artificial intelligence" community by merely increasing the number of search terms.

sections.heading: 3.1. Global connection
sections.text: In general, Figure 2 maps the coauthor network on the globe. Each line is the geological great circle (i.e. the shortest path between two points on the sphere) of the associated organizations. Of the 4,954,982 coauthor relationships between the authors, we get Figure 2. Global networking of universities, institutes, companies, and other research institutes 6486,120 connections between 29,820 organizations. The connections are all in Figure 2. On the map, it is clear that most researchers are located in the United States of America, China, Japan, and some European countries such as the United Kingdom, Germany, and France. Research in Brazil, Singapore, India, and Australia is also very active. These national differences are more evident in Figure 3, which accumulates connections to countries. It is significant that the United States and China are leading partners in global research cooperation. Japan, although geologically closely connected to China, is more closely connected with European and academic countries.

sections.heading: 3.2. Global distribution
sections.text: With the method described in 3.3, we also obtain maps of activity in each area of AI. It could be seen that the research institutes in areas such as data mining, computer vision, pattern recognition and some other areas of machine learning are fairly uniform, implying strong interaction between the community of each field. The most active research has been conducted in the institutes of the United States, China, Singapore and the United Kingdom. Despite the consistency, there is a small but interesting difference in such areas, that the activity in computer vision, pattern recognition, data mining in descending order for the Western countries (the United States and England), but the rise for the Eastern countries (China and Singapore). It is also clear that the United States are extremely competitive in the research of electronic engineering, especially for the California institutes, which are very strong in the combination of AI with industrial and commercial products.

sections.heading: 3.3. From keywords to fields
sections.text: In order to analyze the presentation of entities in different areas, we need a table to assign each keyword to a specific subfield of the AI. There are some ways to accomplish such a procedure as ontology, clustering or just the field manually. In this evaluation, we have the classification via clustering and then manually checks the result.We monitor the most popular 1000 keywords and build a network of their correlations. Each of the keywords of the same paper are associated with an unregulated edge of weight 1, then double edges are accumulated. After building the keyword network, which uses 1000 keywords and 542,048 edges with a total weight of 3,716,812 to recognize the structure of the community.

sections.heading: 3.4. Hot words
sections.text: With the field correspondence keyword we received in Section 3.3, we have undertaken further research into the hot words of the last 5 years, covering the 5-year span from 2009 to 2013. As this research is conducted in mid-October, some of the words published in 2013 may not be available at the time our data was collected, the result is shown in Figure 7. It is clearly shown that technically neutral words are generally more popular. "Data Mining," "learning," "training," "computational modeling" are all among the hottest 10 keywords. "Support Vector Machines" as a technology-specific term seems to be an exception, which is the third hottest keyword. "Feature Extraction," the second hottest keyword profiting from increased attention in computer vision and pattern recognition, is neither as neutral as DM nor as specific as SVM. Meanwhile, "educational institutions" may be a dark horse for the MOOC movement in full swing.

sections.heading: 4. Chronological analysis
sections.text: In addition to the features discussed in Section 3, there may be some more inspiring information. While static analysis provides us with a general status of AI research or status 12, chronological analysis can tell us how it will turn out. In this section, we have broken down the data set by year of publication and reapplied some of the analyses performed in Section 3 to find out how the AI community has evolved over the last 73 years (1940-2013).
